channel.title: Could someone with cracking skills assist me?
channel.description:
Alright, so when it comes to the technical side of things I am a pretty big noob.
So, a couple of people have told me that it's possible to crack the source code of a blitz3d application easily. Since I have no idea how to test this, I thought I'd post a simple 5-minute-to-write application here and see if you can get the sourcecode from it.
http://uppit.com/dl/vLKIqbzY
It's a clean 1 mb size file, basically your a 3d ball and you move around some ramps and crap. I asked the question on two forums already and they say a bunch of crap on how they don't support cracking in anyway shape or form, etc..
So if anyone is able to obtain the source code, please say so. I need to know for security reasons. I need to know if the source-code is obtainable or not.

item.title: Could someone with cracking skills assist me?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Some programs are not compiled. Rather, the source code is combined with an interpreter that basically converts the code to machine language as you're running the program.

Yes that is how it is done.

The reason I am worried is because I dont want people editing the client of my game I am working on *Points to sig. Thanks for the reply, that was very helpful. The program I posted was only a test.

And thanks afi, I’ll take a look.[br][size=1]Posted at: June 03, 2006, 08:54:40 pm[/size][hr]For anyone interested, here is the source code

[code]Const gravity#=-0.03
Graphics3D 800,600,16,1
Const ball_col=1
Const world_col=2
Collisions ball_col,world_col,2,2
Global texture

texture=CreateTexture(16,16)
SetBuffer TextureBuffer(texture)
Color 0,0,0
Rect 0,0,16,16,1
Color 0,0,250
Rect 0,0,8,8,1
Rect 8,8,8,8,1
ScaleTexture texture,0.1,0.1

Global groundtexture=CreateTexture(32,32,1+8)
SetBuffer TextureBuffer(groundtexture)
Color 0,0,0
Rect 0,0,64,64,1
Color 0,255,0
Rect 0,0,64,64,0
ScaleTexture groundtexture,2,2
SetBuffer BackBuffer()
Color 255,255,255

plane=CreatePlane()
EntityTexture plane,groundtexture
EntityType plane,world_col
EntityAlpha plane,0.5
mirror=CreateMirror()
light=CreateLight(1)
RotateEntity light,30,20,0

obj=CreateCube()
EntityType obj,world_col
PositionEntity obj,0,0,0
ScaleEntity obj,10,10,10
RotateEntity obj,45,0,0

obj2=CreateCube()
EntityType obj2,world_col
PositionEntity obj2,30,0,0
ScaleEntity obj2,10,10,10
RotateEntity obj2,45,0,0

obj3=CreateCube()
EntityType obj3,world_col
PositionEntity obj3,-30,0,-20
ScaleEntity obj3,10,10,10
RotateEntity obj3,45,90,0

obj4=CreateCube()
EntityType obj4,world_col
PositionEntity obj4,0,0,40
ScaleEntity obj4,10,10,10
RotateEntity obj4,45,0,0

obj5=CreateCone()
EntityType obj5,world_col
PositionEntity obj5,60,10,35
ScaleEntity obj5,10,10,10
RotateEntity obj5,45,0,90

camera=CreateCamera()
CameraClsColor camera,0,0,255
ball.ball=ballnew(0,4,-120,2,0.8)
zoom#=14
Repeat
zoom#=zoom#-MouseZSpeed()
ballcamera(camera,ball,0,zoom#,-zoom#,0,5,0)
ballcontrol()
ballupdate()

RenderWorld()
Text 10,10,“Arrow keys to control ball”
Text 10,30,“Scroll on mouse to zoom”
Flip
Until KeyDown(1)
End

Type ball
Field e
Field sphere
Field pivot
Field x#,y#,z#
Field vx#,vy#,vz#
Field ax#,ay#,az#
Field size#
Field bounce#
Field vel#
Field vx2#,vy2#,vz2#
End Type

Function ballnew.ball(x#,y#,z#,size#=1,bounce#=0.9)
c.ball=New ball
cx#=x#
cy#=y#
cz#=z#
csize=size
counce#=bounce#
ce=CreatePivot()
csphere=CreateSphere(64)
cpivot=CreatePivot()

EntityType ce,ball_col
EntityRadius ce,csize
PositionEntity ce,cx,cy,cz
ScaleEntity csphere,csize,csize,csize

EntityTexture csphere,texture

Return c

End Function

Function ballupdate()

For c.ball=Each ball

		
	cvy#=cvy#+gravity#
	
	cvx#=cvx#+cax#
	cvy#=cvy#+cay#
	cvz#=cvz#+caz#
	
	cx#=EntityX(ce)
	cy#=EntityY(ce)
	cz#=EntityZ(ce)
	
	TranslateEntity ce,cvx,cvy,cvz	

Next

UpdateWorld()
	
For c.ball=Each ball


	cvx2=(EntityX(ce)-cx)
	cvy2=(EntityY(ce)-cy)
	cvz2=(EntityZ(ce)-cz)
	
	cx#=EntityX(ce)
	cy#=EntityY(ce)
	cz#=EntityZ(ce)
	
	PositionEntity csphere,cx,cy,cz
	PositionEntity cpivot,cx,cy,cz
	
	If EntityCollided(ce,world_col)
			
		For i = 1 To CountCollisions(ce)
			 
			Nx# = CollisionNX(ce, i) 
			Ny# = CollisionNY(ce, i) 
			Nz# = CollisionNZ(ce, i) 
			

			VdotN# = cvx#*Nx# + cvy#*Ny# + cvz#*Nz# 
			

			NFx# = -2.0 * Nx# * VdotN# 
			NFy# = -2.0 * Ny# * VdotN# 
			NFz# = -2.0 * Nz# * VdotN# 
			
			 
			cvx# = cvx# + NFx# * counce#
			cvy# = cvy# + NFy# * counce#
			cvz# = cvz# + NFz# * counce#

			avx#=EntityPitch(csphere)
			avy#=EntityYaw(csphere)
			avz#=EntityRoll(csphere)


			dx1#=(CollisionX(ce,i)-cx)
			dy1#=(CollisionY(ce,i)-cy)
			dz1#=(CollisionZ(ce,i)-cz)
			
			dx2#=cvx
			dy2#=cvy
			dz2#=cvz
			
			
			cx# = ( dy1 * dz2 ) - ( dz1 * dy2 ) 
			cy# = ( dz1 * dx2 ) - ( dx1 * dz2 ) 
			cz# = ( dx1 * dy2 ) - ( dy1 * dx2 ) 				
														
			AlignToVector cpivot,cx,cy,cz,1
																								
		Next
		
		Nx# = CollisionNX(ce, 1) 
		Ny# = CollisionNY(ce, 1) 
		Nz# = CollisionNZ(ce, 1) 				
				
		AlignToVector ce,Nx#,Ny#,Nz#,2,0.5
		
		cvel#=Sqr(cvx2*cvx2+cvy2*cvy2+cvz2*cvz2)
					
		
		cvx#=cvx*0.98
		cvy#=cvy*0.98
		cvz#=cvz*0.98
				

	EndIf

		
	EntityParent csphere,cpivot
							
	TurnEntity cpivot,-cvel#*(180/Pi)/csize#,0,0

	EntityParent csphere,0

	cax#=0
	cay#=0
	caz#=0	
	
Next

End Function

Function ballcontrol()

For c.ball=Each ball
	
	If KeyDown(200)
		
		TFormVector 0,0,0.03,ce,0
		
		cax#=TFormedX()
		cay#=TFormedY()
		caz#=TFormedZ()
		
	EndIf
	
	If KeyDown(208)
		
		cvx=cvx*0.94
		cvy=cvy*0.94
		cvz=cvz*0.94
		
	EndIf
	
	If KeyDown(57)
		
		TFormVector 0,0.05,0,ce,0
		
		cax#=cax+TFormedX()
		cay#=cay+TFormedY()
		caz#=caz+TFormedZ()
		
								
	EndIf
	
	If KeyDown(203)
		
		TurnEntity ce,0,2,0
		
	EndIf
	
	If KeyDown(205)
		
		TurnEntity ce,0,-2,0
		
	EndIf
	
	
Next

End Function

Function ballcamera(camera,b.ball,camx#,camy#,camz#,aimx#=0,aimy#=0,aimz#=0,smoothcam#=0.1,roll#=0)

TFormPoint camx#,camy#,camz#,be,0

dx#=(TFormedX()-EntityX(camera))*smoothcam#
dy#=(TFormedY()-EntityY(camera))*smoothcam#
dz#=(TFormedZ()-EntityZ(camera))*smoothcam#

TranslateEntity camera,dx,dy,dz

TFormPoint aimx#,aimy#,aimz#,be,0

dx# = EntityX(camera)-TFormedX()
dy# = EntityY(camera)-TFormedY()
dz# = EntityZ(camera)-TFormedZ()
dist#=Sqr#((dx#*dx#)+(dz#*dz#))
pitch#=ATan2(dy#,dist#)
yaw#=ATan2(dx#,-dz#)

RotateEntity camera,pitch#,yaw#,roll#

[/code]

Read full topic

item.source: Could someone with cracking skills assist me?

item.title: Could someone with cracking skills assist me?
item.dc:creator: @yetanothercheater yetanothercheater
item.description:
@yetanothercheater wrote:

Most programs are compiled. This means that whatever code you wrote has been converted into machine language that the computer processor actually understands. It’s possible to disassemble programs, which means getting the assembly language version of the source code. However, to get the source code as the programmer wrote it (unless he used assembly) is generally hard or impossible. There are decompilers for some languages, which do this job to some degree, but it’s much harder than disassembling. For example, it’s unlikely that a decompiler will produce the variable names that the original programmer used, since the compiler just changes them to memory locations when making the executable.

Some programs are not compiled. Rather, the source code is combined with an interpreter that basically converts the code to machine language as you’re running the program. This is usually slower than compiling, so fewer programming languages use this method. It might be possible to retrieve the original source from interpreted programs, but I don’t think it would be a trivial task.

I’m not sure why you’re so worried about someone being able to retrieve the source code of your program. Crackers usually use the assembly language output of a disassembler, along with a debugger, to modify programs. Converting the code to a higher-level language is pointless if you know assembly, as you’d be doing much more work than necessary.

I’ve done a few quick searches for Blitz3D decompilers and found nothing but a fake one. This doesn’t mean that one does not exist, but I think it would have popped up in some of the results by now. Have you thought of asking on the official forum (if there is one)? The people there would probably know.

Read full topic
item.source: Could someone with cracking skills assist me?

item.title: Could someone with cracking skills assist me?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

White Castle:

It’s coded in C++, and I don’t think they make decompilers for C++ much less an .exe wrapper.

Like my post said, it’s a blitz3d application that I wrote. Blitz3d is a basic language, can be found here: www.blitzbasic.com
